attributes.title: 10 C# tips and tricks every Unity developer should know
attributes.metaDesc: C# is a powerful programming language that is widely used in game development, particularly with the Unity game engine. If you are a Unity developer looking to improve your skills and productivity, there are many tips and tricks that can help you achieve your goals more efficiently. In this article, we will go over 10 C# tips and tricks every Unity developer should know.

body.content:
As a Unity developer, knowing C# is essential for creating great games. C# is the primary programming language used in Unity, and knowing some tips and tricks can help you write more efficient and maintainable code. In this article, we will discuss 10 C# tips and tricks that every Unity developer should know.

 

  1. Use Unity Events

Unity events are a type of C# delegate that allows you to send messages between components in your game. Let’s say you have a game where the player can pick up different items. When the player picks up an item, you want to update the UI to show the new item. Instead of directly accessing the UI from the item pickup code, you can use a Unity event to notify the UI component of the new item. Here’s an example:

 


using UnityEngine;
using UnityEngine.Events;

public class ItemPickup : MonoBehaviour
{
    public UnityEvent OnPickup;

    private void OnTriggerEnter(Collider other)
    {
        if (other.CompareTag("Player"))
        {
            // Add item to player's inventory
            // ...

            // Notify UI of new item
            OnPickup?.Invoke();
        }
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the ItemPickup component has a public UnityEvent called OnPickup. When the player collides with the item, the OnTriggerEnter method is called, which adds the item to the player’s inventory and then invokes the OnPickup event. Other components in your game can listen for this event and respond accordingly.

 

  1. Avoid public fields

Public fields can be accessed and modified by any component in your game, which can lead to unexpected behavior and bugs. Instead, you should use private fields with properties to control access to them. Let’s say you have a player character that has a health value. Instead of making the health value a public field, you can make it private and provide a public property to get and set the value. Here’s an example:

 


public class Player : MonoBehaviour
{
    private int _health;

    public int Health 
    {
        get { return _health; }
        set 
        { 
            _health = value; 

            // Update UI
            // ...
        }
    }

    private void Start()
    {
        // Initialize health
        Health = 100;
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the Player component has a private int field called _health. Instead of making this field public, we provide a public property called Health that allows other components to get and set the value. When the Health property is set, we also update the UI to reflect the new health value.

 

  1. Use the Singleton Pattern

The Singleton pattern is a design pattern that ensures that there is only one instance of a class in your game. Let’s say you have a game manager class that needs to be accessed from multiple components in your game. Instead of creating multiple instances of the game manager, you can use the Singleton pattern to ensure that there is only one instance. Here’s an example:

 


public class GameManager : MonoBehaviour
{
    private static GameManager _instance;

    public static GameManager Instance 
    {
        get 
        {
            if (_instance == null)
            {
                _instance = FindObjectOfType();
                DontDestroyOnLoad(_instance.gameObject);
            }

            return _instance;
        }
    }

    private void Awake()
    {
        if (_instance != null && _instance != this)
        {
            Destroy(gameObject);
        }
        else
        {
            _instance = this;
            DontDestroyOnLoad(gameObject);
        }
    }

    // Game manager methods
    // ...
}

 

 

In this example, the GameManager component uses a static Instance property to ensure that there is only one instance of the game manager in your game. When the Instance property is accessed, we check if there is already an instance of the game manager. If there is, we return the existing instance. If there isn’t, we search for the game manager in the scene and create a new instance if one doesn’t already exist. We also use the DontDestroyOnLoad method to ensure that the game manager persists between scenes.

 

  1. Use the Null-Conditional Operator

The Null-Conditional Operator (also known as the “safe navigation operator”) is a C# operator that allows you to safely access members of an object without causing a null reference exception. Let’s say you have a player character that can equip different weapons. When the player equips a weapon, you want to play a sound effect. However, if the player doesn’t have an audio source component, you’ll get a null reference exception. You can use the Null-Conditional Operator to safely access the audio source component. Here’s an example:

 


public class Player : MonoBehaviour
{
    private AudioSource _audioSource;

    private void Start()
    {
        _audioSource = GetComponent();
    }

    public void EquipWeapon(Weapon weapon)
    {
        // Equip weapon
        // ...

        // Play sound effect
        _audioSource?.PlayOneShot(weapon.EquipSound);
    }
}

 

In this example, the Player component has a private AudioSource field called _audioSource. When the Start method is called, we get the audio source component attached to the player. When the player equips a weapon, we use the Null-Conditional Operator to safely access the audio source component and play the equip sound effect.

 

  1. Use the nameof Operator

The nameof operator is a C# operator that returns the name of a variable, type, or member as a string. This can be useful when you need to pass the name of a variable or member as a parameter to a method. Let’s say you have a game where the player can collect different types of resources. When the player collects a resource, you want to update the UI to show the new resource count. Instead of hardcoding the resource name in the UI code, you can use the nameof operator to pass the name of the resource as a parameter. Here’s an example:

 


public class ResourceManager : MonoBehaviour
{
    public int WoodCount { get; private set; }
    public int StoneCount { get; private set; }

    public void CollectResource(ResourceType resourceType, int amount)
    {
        switch (resourceType)
        {
            case ResourceType.Wood:
                WoodCount += amount;
                break;
            case ResourceType.Stone:
                StoneCount += amount;
                break;
        }

        // Update UI
        UIManager.Instance.UpdateResourceCount(nameof(resourceType), amount);
    }
}

public class UIManager : MonoBehaviour
{
    public void UpdateResourceCount(string resourceName, int amount)
    {
        // Update UI with resource count
        // ...
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the ResourceManager component has public properties for the resource counts. When the player collects a resource, we use a switch statement to update the appropriate count. We then use the nameof operator to pass the name of the resource to the UpdateResourceCount method in the UIManager component.

 

  1. Use the ?? Operator

The ?? operator (also known as the null coalescing operator) is a C# operator that allows you to provide a default value for a nullable variable. Let’s say you have a game where the player can pick up different items that have different values. When the player sells an item, you want to add the item’s value to the player’s money count. However, if the item doesn’t have a value, you’ll get a null reference exception. You can use the ?? operator to provide a default value for the item’s value. Here’s an example:

 


public class Item : MonoBehaviour
{
    public int? Value;
}

public class Inventory : MonoBehaviour
{
    private List _items = new List();

    public void SellItem(Item item)
    {
        int value = item.Value ?? 0;
        Player.Instance.AddMoney(value);

        _items.Remove(item);
        Destroy(item.gameObject);
    }
}

public class Player : MonoBehaviour
{
    public static Player Instance { get; private set; }
    public int Money { get; private set; }

    private void Awake()
    {
        if (Instance == null)
        {
            Instance = this;
        }
        else
        {
            Destroy(gameObject);
        }
    }

    public void AddMoney(int amount)
    {
        Money += amount;
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the Item component has a nullable Value field that represents the value of the item. When the player sells an item, we use the ?? operator to provide a default value of 0 if the item’s value is null. We then add the value to the player’s money count using the AddMoney method in the Player component.

 

  1. Use the yield return Statement

The yield return statement is a C# statement that allows you to return a sequence of values from a method. This can be useful when you want to iterate over a collection of objects, but you don’t want to load all the objects into memory at once. Let’s say you have a game where the player can find different types of items in the world. Instead of loading all the items into memory at once, you can use the yield return statement to iterate over the items one at a time. Here’s an example:

 


public class ItemGenerator : MonoBehaviour
{
    public List ItemPrefabs;

    public IEnumerable GenerateItems()
    {
        while (true)
        {
            int index = Random.Range(0, ItemPrefabs.Count);
            Item prefab = ItemPrefabs[index];
            Item item = Instantiate(prefab);

            yield return item;
        }
    }
}

public class ItemCollector : MonoBehaviour
{
    public Inventory Inventory;

    private void OnTriggerEnter(Collider other)
    {
        if (other.CompareTag("Item"))
        {
            Item item = other.GetComponent();
            Inventory.AddItem(item);

            Destroy(other.gameObject);
        }
    }
}

public class Inventory : MonoBehaviour
{
    private List _items = new List();

    public void AddItem(Item item)
    {
        _items.Add(item);
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the ItemGenerator component has a list of Item prefabs. The GenerateItems method uses the yield return statement to create and return a new item from the list each time it's called. The ItemCollector component checks for collision with items and adds them to the inventory using the AddItem method in the Inventory component.

 

  1. Use the switch Expression

The switch expression is a new feature introduced in C# 8 that allows you to use switch statements as expressions instead of statements. This can make your code more concise and easier to read. Let’s say you have a game where the player can perform different types of attacks. Each attack has a different animation that plays. Instead of using a long switch statement to select the animation, you can use the switch expression. Here’s an example:

 


public class Player : MonoBehaviour
{
    public Animator Animator;

    public void Attack(AttackType attackType)
    {
        string animationName = attackType switch
        {
            AttackType.Light => "LightAttack",
            AttackType.Heavy => "HeavyAttack",
            _ => throw new ArgumentException("Invalid attack type"),
        };

        Animator.Play(animationName);
    }
}

public enum AttackType
{
    Light,
    Heavy,
}

 

 

In this example, the Player component has an Animator field that represents the player’s animation controller. The Attack method takes an AttackType parameter that specifies the type of attack to perform. The switch expression is used to select the animation to play based on the attack type. If the attack type is not recognized, an exception is thrown. The Animator.Play method is used to play the animation.

 

  1. Use C# 9 Records

C# 9 introduced the concept of records, which are immutable classes that can be used to represent data. Records are concise and easy to read, and they provide a lot of useful functionality out of the box. Let’s say you have a game where you need to keep track of the player’s health and position. You can use a record to represent this data. Here’s an example:

 


public record PlayerData(int Health, Vector3 Position);

public class Player : MonoBehaviour
{
    public PlayerData Data { get; private set; }

    private void Start()
    {
        Data = new PlayerData(100, transform.position);
    }

    private void Update()
    {
        Data = Data with { Position = transform.position };
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the PlayerData record represents the player's health and position. The Player component has a Data field that represents the player's data. The Start method initializes the data, and the Update method updates the position.

 

  1. Use Events

Events are a C# feature that allows you to notify other components when something happens in your game. Events are useful for decoupling components and making your code more modular. Let’s say you have a game where the player can pick up items. You can use an event to notify other components when an item is picked up. Here’s an example:

 


public class Item : MonoBehaviour
{
    public event EventHandler OnPickedUp;

    private void OnTriggerEnter(Collider other)
    {
        if (other.CompareTag("Player"))
        {
            OnPickedUp?.Invoke(this, EventArgs.Empty);
        }
    }
}

public class Inventory : MonoBehaviour
{
    private List _items = new List();

    private void Start()
    {
        foreach (Item item in FindObjectsOfType())
        {
            item.OnPickedUp += OnItemPickedUp;
        }
    }

    private void OnItemPickedUp(object sender, EventArgs e)
    {
        Item item = (Item)sender;
        _items.Add(item);
        Destroy(item.gameObject);
    }
}

 

 

In this example, the Item component has an OnPickedUp event that is raised when the item is picked up. The Inventory component subscribes to the event for all Item components in the scene using the Start method. When an item is picked up, the OnItemPickedUp method is called, which adds the item to the inventory and destroys the item’s game object.

 

Using events can make your code more modular and flexible, as it allows components to interact with each other without having to know about each other’s implementation details.

 

Conclusion

In conclusion, these are just a few of the C# tips and tricks that can make your Unity development experience more enjoyable and efficient. By using these techniques, you can write cleaner, more readable, and more maintainable code. Keep in mind that C# is a powerful language with many features and capabilities, and there is always more to learn. Continuously improve your coding skills and knowledge, and you will become a better Unity developer.
